title: The Power of Pets in Living With MG

content: There's a special kind of comfort that comes from being around animals, especially when you face the unpredictability of myasthenia gravis (MG).

My journey has been challenging, but my pets transform those challenges into moments of joy and connection. They aren’t just animals. They are my lifeline, offering companionship that grounds me even on the toughest days. The love and loyalty they give make every hurdle worthwhile and fill my life with a sense of purpose and warmth.

My dog, an energetic yet surprisingly calm, large, mixed breed, is at the center of this companionship. He’s filled with quirks, and has the funniest, cutest personality. He lifts my spirits, no matter how tough a day has been.

When my condition was at its worst, and I was pretty much bedridden, my dog was invaluable. I felt shut off from the outside world, and my friendships had broken down because I couldn’t do anything outside the house. But he was always by my side, offering comfort and a connection to the world that I so desperately needed. He’s incredibly loyal and loving, always there for me, especially when I’m feeling ill or sad.

content: But there are times when the challenges of MG make it difficult for me to take him on daily walks. The guilt I feel during those times can be overwhelming. Seeing the confusion in his eyes, not understanding why we aren’t going on our usual outings, can break my heart. I see him waiting by the door, not knowing that my body simply can’t keep up that day.
Thankfully, my family steps in to help, but the look he gives me during those times lingers in my mind

After a particularly bad fall from MG that sent me to the hospital, my family had never seen him so heartbroken, waiting by the door for my return. Fortunately, he’s quite relaxed most of the time, often sleeping through the day, except when he insists on his two daily walks or wants a bit of playtime.

content: His affectionate nature makes him the perfect companion, and his persistence with walks keeps me moving, even when MG makes it challenging.

content: Along with my loyal dog, I have three outdoor rabbits who add their unique joys and challenges. These adventurous little creatures love to roam the garden, often turning it into a game when it’s time to return to their hutch. On days when MG flares, chasing after them can be exhausting. But their playful antics and calming presence make the effort more than worthwhile. The weekly task of cleaning their hutch is another challenge, but it’s one I’m willing to take on because of the peace and happiness they bring into my life.

Thankfully, I don’t have to manage everything on my own. My family helps out with my dog and rabbits, ensuring they’re well cared for when I need extra rest. I’m sure my friends would also pitch in if I needed additional support.

That said, think long and hard about getting a pet when you have a chronic illness, if you don’t have a support system to help. The love and companionship of pets are incredible, but the responsibility can be overwhelming, especially when your health is its worst.

content: Being a big animal lover, I know that despite the challenges, I’ll likely add more pets to my family in the future. No matter how difficult their care can be at times, the love, companionship, and joy they bring into my life make it all so, so worth it.
